Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2013
Award.AbstractNarration:
A variable world: Integrating population-level variation and climatic variation to predict climate change impacts

This project examines how differences in thermal physiology and climatic variation affect predictions about impacts of climate change on population and species viability in temperate and tropical regions. Using dung beetles, variation in thermal physiology will be quantified among and within species across broad latitudinal and elevational gradients. These detailed physiological data will be incorporated into a model that alters the magnitude and time course of climatic variation, allowing for an assessment of how physiological variation and climatic variation affect predictions about the impacts of climate change. The model will be applied to assessing population viability in other systems where the temperature dependence of population growth rate is known or can be calculated from principles in biological scaling.

Training objectives include becoming fluent in developing and applying mathematical models to ecological studies. By combining detailed physiological data with climatic variation, the mathematical model developed during the fellowship will provide a more realistic assessment of climate change impacts across latitude. The project will add specimens to beetle collections in the USA and abroad, providing a locality-based record that can be used for teaching and research. Working internationally will allow interaction and collaboration with foreign students and colleagues, offering unique opportunities for teaching, training and learning for all parties involved. Results will be disseminated through scientific publications, presentations, and outreach and help guide national and international conservation efforts by providing an understanding of which species may be most at risk in a warming world. The third year teaching option will support the development of effective teaching in undergraduate classrooms by incorporating and assessing active learning techniques.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Studies have typically used shifts in mean temperature to understand how temperature change impacts species and ecological communities. However, other changes in temperature, including greater temperature variation and more frequent extreme events, could pose greater risks for organisms than shifts in mean temperature alone. A major goal of this project was to understand how differences in thermal physiology and climatic variation affect predictions about impacts of temperature variation on species across latitude. To accomplish this goal, the postdoctoral fellow compared how temperature extremes and increased temperature variation affect species in tropical and temperate environments. Specifically, detailed data on physiological traits (i.e. thermal performance curves and critical thermal limits of insects and degree days of corn) for species across latitude were combined with high-resolution temperature data from around the world to assess how shifts in temperature variation versus shifts in mean temperature affect organisms. Results indicated that using mean temperatures to make predictions does a poor job of capturing cryptic, or hidden, changes in temperature that can greatly impact species and ecological communities. This suggests that incorporating both detailed physiological data and high frequency temperature data provide better predictions of how species may respond to temperature change. These findings advance our understanding of the ways in which species and ecological communities are impacted by temperature changes beyond shifts in mean temperature alone. The results can help guide national and international conservation and food security efforts by providing an understanding of how species across latitude may respond to shifts in temperature variation and thermal extremes.

Another major goal of the project was to develop and test innovative techniques for education. Two university-level courses stemmed from the project. The postdoctoral fellow developed an R Programming course for graduate students at the University of Wyoming (UW). The course incorporated active learning techniques using the students' own data. Students completed and presented projects on the data manipulations and analyses they had performed in R. The materials developed for this course were transferred to an instructor at UW where they can be used for future classes. The materials are also being incorporated into an introductory ecology laboratory at the University of Tennessee to teach programming to incoming undergraduates. As part of the project, the postdoctoral fellow also developed a field-based tropical ecology course in Ecuador. The goals of the course are to 1) introduce students to topics in tropical biodiversity, sustainability, and conservation from both social and ecological angles, and 2) teach students to become independent scientists through field-based research projects. The course is designed to provide students with the skills and confidence necessary to produce high-quality research and to understand and evaluate scientific findings.

Other goals of the project were to improve natural history collections by providing records of insect specimens and to strengthen global networks and partnerships. To reach these goals, the postdoctoral fellow traveled to a field site in South America and collaborated with an Ecuadorean scientist. The fellow also pinned insect specimens for natural history collections and participated in a BioBlitz event in Tennessee. The goal of the BioBlitz was to document biodiversity in urban forests, teach the public about collecting and identifying insects, and get local citizens excited about nature. Alongside citizens, the postdoctoral fellow collected 405 specimens, identified 124 species, and posted digital photos to iNaturalist (www.iNaturalist.org). Through participation in the BioBlitz, the postdoctoral fellow was able to engage a wider audience in science and nature. The digital images posted on iNaturalist provide a valuable record that can be used for teaching and research far into the future.

A major training objective for the postdoctoral fellow was to become fluent in developing and applying mathematical models to ecological studies. During the fellowship period, the postdoctoral fellow modeled the impacts of climatic variation on species across latitude. The fellow also collaborated with mathematicians and physicists to develop mathematical models of the aerial dispersal of spiders. Spiders benefit humans by eating harmful insects such as those that destroy agricultural crops. Young spiders “balloon” through the air on silk threads to disperse to new environments where they provide valuable ecosystem services. However, we do not understand the physics behind this dispersal. This interdisciplinary collaboration on spider dispersal generated new multi-scale fluid dynamic models and numerical methods, both of which are required to simulate long distance transport of small animals. These models and methods advance understanding in the fields of fluid dynamics, mathematics, and biological dispersal, and improved the postdoctoral fellow’s ability to apply such models to future work.

The results of this research were disseminated through scientific publications, international and national presentations, and through public outreach events.
